anchor.surface_text: A memorandum of appeal, as provided in article 1 of Schedule I of the Court-Fees Act, has to be stamped according to the value of the subject-matter in dispute in appeal in other words, the relief claimed in the memorandum of appeal determines the value of the appeal for purposes of court-fee.

arguments.claim: Judicial consensus limits section 12 finality to valuation simpliciter/appraisement, not category of suit/appeal for court-fee

anchor.surface_text: In a number of decisions the Calcutta High Court took the view... The High Court of Lahore has placed a similar construction the meaning of the expression valuation in section 12... The Madras High Court took the same view...

arguments.claim: Difference in phraseology between sections 5 and 12 Court-Fees Act indicates narrower scope for S.12: finality only for valuation/appraisement, not all fee questions or category (law)

anchor.surface_text: The difference in the phraseology employed in sections 5 and 12 of the Court-Fees Act indicates that the scope of section 12 is narrower than that of section 5. Section 5 which declares decisions questions of court-fee whenever they arise in the chartered High Courts as final

arguments.claim: Category determination is pure question of law antecedent to, but not part of, valuation/appraisement for court-fee

anchor.surface_text: Whether a case falls under one particular section of the Act or another is a pure question of law and does not directly determine the valuation of the suit for purposes of court-fee. The question of determination of valuation or appraisement only arises after it is settled in what class or category it falls.

arguments.claim: Judicial Commissioner's decision not covered by section 12 finality as it decided maintainability/merits (need for relief 2), not fee valuation or category

anchor.surface_text: Conceding for the sake of argument but not admitting-that Mr. Setalvad is right... in the present case the Judicial Commissioner decided neither of these questions and his decision cannot be said to be one falling within the ambit of section 12.

holdings.text: the order demanding additional court-fee the memorandum of appeal as it stood, that is, minus the second prayer, was erroneous and we hold that the memorandum of appeal was properly stamped, as the subject-matter of the appeal was purely of a declaratory character.

anchor.surface_text: We are thus of the opinion that the order demanding additional court-fee the memorandum of appeal as it stood, that is, minus the second prayer, was erroneous and we hold that the memorandum of appeal was properly stamped, as the subject-matter of the appeal was purely of a declaratory character.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relief claimed in memo is only first declaratory prayer after relinquishing second; appellant entitled to restrict claim; proper fee under Art 17 Sch II based on relief in memo.

holdings.text: For the purpose of deciding whether the memorandum of appeal was properly stamped according to the subjectmatter of the appeal, it was not open to the Judicial Commissioner to canvass the question whether the suit with the second prayer eliminated from it fell within the mischief of the proviso to section 42 of the Specific Relief Act. That was a question which related to the merits of the appeal and did not concern its proper institution

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of deciding whether the memorandum of appeal was properly stamped according to the subjectmatter of the appeal, it was not open to the Judicial Commissioner to canvass the question whether the suit with the second prayer eliminated from it fell within the mischief of the proviso to section 42 of the Specific Relief Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Determining s42 proviso applicability is merits issue, not relevant to stamping or proper institution of appeal.

holdings.text: The claim contained in the first relief of the plaint is to the effect that it be declared that defendant No. 2 has no right to act as chairman an managing director because of his appointment being illegal, invalid, and ultra vires. The declaration claimed is in negative form that defendant No. 2 has no right to act as chairman and managing director. No claim for a consequential relief can be read within this prayer.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree. The claim contained in the first relief of the plaint is to the effect that it be declared that defendant No. 2 has no right to act as chairman an managing director because of his appointment being illegal, invalid, and ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prayer is negative declaration of invalidity and no right to act; words 'no right to act' reiterate declaration, do not imply consequential relief.

holdings.text: We think that the construction given to the language in section 12 in these decisions is right... the finality declared by section 12 only related to matters of, appraisement... finality attaches only to a decision which concerns valuation simpliciter and no finality attaches when a court decides a question whether a case falls within one or other category

anchor.surface_text: We think that the construction given to the language in section 12 in these decisions is right, and our reasons for saying so are these The difference in the phraseology employed in sections 5 and 12 of the Court-Fees Act indicates that the scope of section 12 is narrower than that of section 5.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consensus of judicial opinion limits s12 finality to valuation/appraisement (factual), excludes category (law) and merits; narrower than s5 phraseology; harmonious with CPC OVII R11 appealability of rejections as decrees.

holdings.text: in the present case the Judicial Commissioner decided neither of these questions and his decision cannot be said to be one falling within the ambit of section 12. All that the Judicial Commissioner decided was that as the suit could not be maintained without asking for relief No. 2, the same fee was payable the memorandum of appeal as the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: Conceding for the sake of argument but not admitting-that Mr. Setalvad is right in his contention that section 12 is comprehensive enough to include within its ambit all questions relating to court-fee whether they involve a decision as to question of category or as to valuation simpliciter,

holdings.reasoning_summary: JC decided maintainability/merits (necessity of relief 2), not valuation or category; outside s12 scope even on broad view.

holdings.text: The difference in the phraseology employed in sections 5 and 12 of the Court-Fees Act indicates that the scope of section 12 is narrower than that of section 5.

anchor.surface_text: The difference in the phraseology employed in sections 5 and 12 of the Court-Fees Act indicates that the scope of section 12 is narrower than that of section 5. Section 5 which declares decisions questions of court-fee whenever they arise in the chartered High Courts as final

holdings.reasoning_summary: S5 broader (all fee questions final in chartered HCs), s12 limited to 'valuation for determining amount'; different language implies different intent.

holdings.text: Whether a case falls under one particular section of the Act or another is a pure question of law and does not directly determine the valuation of the suit for purposes of court-fee.

anchor.surface_text: Whether a case falls under one particular section of the Act or another is a pure question of law and does not directly determine the valuation of the suit for purposes of court-fee. The question of determination of valuation or appraisement only arises after it is settled in what class or category it falls.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Category decision antecedent and independent (law), valuation/appraisement follows (factual/arithmetic/expert).

anchor.surface_text: Whether a case falls under one particular section of the Act or another is a pure question of law and does not directly determine the valuation of the suit for purposes of court-fee. The question of determination of valuation or appraisement only arises after it is settled in what class or category it falls.

We are thus of the opinion that the order demanding additional companyrt-fee the memorandum of appeal as it stood, that is, minus the second prayer, was erroneous and we hold that the memorandum of appeal was properly stamped, as the subject
